paragraphs.name: 6ec5
paragraphs.text:
Naïve. Super by Erlend Loe
Another funny and entertaining book. Loe is from Norway, and I like his minimal style. It’s a story about a young kid who’s searching for meaning in life. Way better than all the corny self-help parables like The Alchemist. This book down to earth and fun to read.

paragraphs.name: 8e97
paragraphs.text: P.S. What’s your favorite fiction book? Feel free to share it in the comments.

Death With Interruptions by Jose Saramago
We all die, right? But what if that wasn’t the case? A lot of people are afraid of death, but in this novel, people don’t have to be afraid anymore. Because on the first day of the new year, no one dies. Death basically gives up her job (yes, death is a her in this book). What happens next? Read the book. It’s really good.
paragraphs.name: 6c1f

paragraphs.text:

Another funny and entertaining book. Loe is from Norway, and I like his minimal style. It’s a story about a young kid who’s searching for meaning in life. Way better than all the corny self-help parables like The Alchemist. This book is down to earth and fun to read.

paragraphs.text: “What really knocks me out is a book that, when you’re all done reading it, you wish the author that wrote it was a terrific friend of yours and you could call him up on the phone whenever you felt like it. That doesn’t happen much, though.”

virtuals.subtitle: (Chuck Palahniuk actually handed me a first edition of Fight Club many moons ago. It holds a special place in my home).

paragraphs.text: One criminally underrated book and one that truly changed the way I think, is Shantaram by Gregory David Roberts. It does an excellent job at giving words to those emotions that you cannot attribute words to. I cannot praise this book enough.

content.subtitle: Casey McGregor is a high school sophomore living in Salem, OR who lost the birth lottery — abandoned by his mother to an alcoholic father…

paragraphs.name: 7b31
paragraphs.text: I’d have to say Sometimes a Great Notion, by Ken Kesey is one of those books for me — both the way it’s written as well as its subject matter. I’d say I hate to toot my own horn, but since clearly I don’t, I encourage people to check out Cherry City Pulp, my first novel. I guarantee you’ve read nothing like it before. Blurb is below.

af3104948bd7.title: Ha!! I literally just finished reading The Alchemist again and fell madly in love with it this time…

paragraphs.name: 5eb6
paragraphs.text: Ha!! I literally just finished reading The Alchemist again and fell madly in love with it this time around. I think I must’ve been in a different place the first time and I just didn’t connect with it. Probably the thing with books. Their appreciation depends on your state of mind at the time.

7c45e7a39173.title: The Gods of Tango by Carolina de Robertis.

paragraphs.name: 54af
paragraphs.text: The Gods of Tango by Carolina de Robertis. Actually every book of hers is extraordinary, but this is my favorite. As well as an extraordinary story, it is an excellent history lesson of Argentina in the early 1900’s and has a surprising LGBTQ factor.

paragraphs.name: e783
paragraphs.text: To really change my mind, I gave up reading white dudes, and mostly read fiction by women, and stories by African-Americans. Here’s a few that may improve your thinking. Because 49.6% of us worldwide are women, and 14% of your choices here are women, and yes, that’s patriarchy in action.

content.subtitle: 1984 by George Orwell. It makes you realize how important, beautiful and precious Freedom is. We must protect it with all we have.

paragraphs.name: 32c0
paragraphs.text: I believe that every book you read teaches you something, if you want to learn. Non-fiction books are full of knowledge and facts but fictions teach you something far more important and valuable— empathy, new perspectives, story telling, understanding others, patience and so much more. EQ is as important as IQ, if not more. These aren’t my favourite…

e6a80ca38004.title: If you are looking for a simple, thought-provoking fiction book, give The Phantom Tollbooth a read.

paragraphs.name: e853
paragraphs.text: If you are looking for a simple, thought-provoking fiction book, give The Phantom Tollbooth a read. It’s technically a children’s book, but my wife turned me onto it a few years ago and I found it so insightful!

83d0242cbda4.title: Cloud Atlas by David Mitchell all the way.

paragraphs.name: 536b
paragraphs.text: Cloud Atlas by David Mitchell all the way. I love the structure of this book and it opened my eyes to how diverse the fiction genre can be.

virtuals.subtitle: This novel has some universal elements that make a rather simple plot expansive and compelling.

a95202921fcc.title: For me, I found Mercedes Lackey’s Valdemar stories (science fiction) incredibly helpful as I grew…

paragraphs.name: f80a
paragraphs.text: For me, I found Mercedes Lackey’s Valdemar stories (science fiction) incredibly helpful as I grew and matured. When you come from a place where cows outnumber people, handling diversity in a positive way can be challenging. Through her stories, I saw positive social structure for handling diversity that I could imitate.

632751f1b40b.title: East of Eden, by John Steinbeck.

paragraphs.name: e5bb
paragraphs.text: East of Eden, by John Steinbeck. I read it at least once a year. It seems to touch on the things I fail to ruminate on of my own accord: identity, the facets and consequences of love, human goodness. It’s an important novel.

b68a2bae66eb.title: For years I have been stuck in a pattern of only consuming non-fiction.

paragraphs.name: 453f
paragraphs.text: For years I have been stuck in a pattern of only consuming non-fiction. My theory is (or has been), if I’m not learning from it, it’s not worth my time. Your article is timely for me…as I’ve been gently encouraged by my therapist to allow my brain to relax a little and read some fiction. I will start with #1. Thanks for this list…you probably have no idea how helpful it is to me.

virtuals.subtitle: Thanks to my dad who had instilled a passion for literature in me from the age of six , I never needed to be told I should read.
